name: Coq au Vin
description: Recipe video above. Coq au Vin is the well known French stew where chicken pieces are braised in a luscious, glossy red wine sauce with bacon, mushroom and onions. Like Beef Bourguignon, the beauty of this dish lies in its simplicity: remarkably few ingredients and simple process with results fit for a king – or queen! For the best results, start this 2 days before serving: 12 - 24 hour marinade for the chicken (essential), then rest the finished stew overnight to let the flavours develop even further (recommended but not essential).Recipe source: Another classic French recipe brought to you via Chef Jean-Baptiste Alexandre, our culinary collaborator for all things French. Because I like to do traditional recipes properly!
recipeIngredient: 4  chicken thighs (, bone-in, skin on (~220g / 7 oz each) (Note 1))
750 ml / 3 cups  pinot noir red wine (, or other dry red wine (Note 3))
3/4 tsp salt ((cooking/kosher salt, or 1/2 tsp table salt))
150g / 5oz  bacon piece (, (speck) cut into 1 x 2.5cm / 0.4 x 1" batons (Note 5))
1/4 tsp salt ((cooking/kosher salt, or 1/8 tsp table salt) (Note 7))

itemListElement.text: Marinate chicken: Place the Chicken Marinade ingredients in a large glass or ceramic bowl or dish. Marinate overnight in the fridge (minimum 12 hours, maximum 24 hours).
itemListElement.name: Marinate chicken: Place the Chicken Marinade ingredients in a large glass or ceramic bowl or dish. Marinate overnight in the fridge (minimum 12 hours, maximum 24 hours).

itemListElement.text: Strain wine into a bowl. Reserve herbs and wine. Separate the chicken and onion.
itemListElement.name: Strain wine into a bowl. Reserve herbs and wine. Separate the chicken and onion.

itemListElement.text: Dry chicken: Spread chicken out on a try lined with paper towels, then pat dry with paper towels.
itemListElement.name: Dry chicken: Spread chicken out on a try lined with paper towels, then pat dry with paper towels.

itemListElement.text: Reduce wine: Pour red wine into a saucepan and bring to a boil over medium high heat. Simmer vigorously, skimming off any impurities that rise to the surface, until reduced by half. Set aside.
itemListElement.name: Reduce wine: Pour red wine into a saucepan and bring to a boil over medium high heat. Simmer vigorously, skimming off any impurities that rise to the surface, until reduced by half. Set aside.

itemListElement.text: Season chicken: Sprinkle chicken with 3/4 tsp salt and 1/2 tsp black pepper.
itemListElement.name: Season chicken: Sprinkle chicken with 3/4 tsp salt and 1/2 tsp black pepper.

itemListElement.text: Brown chicken: Heat 3 tbsp oil in a large, heavy-based, oven-proof pot over medium-high heat. Add chicken thighs skin side down and cook for 2 - 3 minutes until nicely browned (it will be darker than usual because of the red wine). Flip thighs and cook the other side for another minute to kiss it with a little colour. Remove to a tray. Pull at skin of drumsticks to cover flesh as best as possible, then brown (I do 3 to 4 sides, ~5 minutes in total). Remove and set aside.
itemListElement.name: Brown chicken: Heat 3 tbsp oil in a large, heavy-based, oven-proof pot over medium-high heat. Add chicken thighs skin side down and cook for 2 - 3 minutes until nicely browned (it will be darker than usual because of the red wine). Flip thighs and cook the other side for another minute to kiss it with a little colour. Remove to a tray. Pull at skin of drumsticks to cover flesh as best as possible, then brown (I do 3 to 4 sides, ~5 minutes in total). Remove and set aside.

itemListElement.text: Fry bacon: Remove any loose black burnt bits. Add a bit of extra oil if needed, then cook bacon for 3 minutes until golden. Add to tray with chicken.
itemListElement.name: Fry bacon: Remove any loose black burnt bits. Add a bit of extra oil if needed, then cook bacon for 3 minutes until golden. Add to tray with chicken.

itemListElement.text: Sauté mushrooms: Add mushrooms and cook for 5 minutes, or until golden. Remove into a separate bowl.
itemListElement.name: Sauté mushrooms: Add mushrooms and cook for 5 minutes, or until golden. Remove into a separate bowl.

itemListElement.text: Sauté onion: Add a bit of extra oil if needed, then cook onions for 5 minutes or until there are nice golden patches.
itemListElement.name: Sauté onion: Add a bit of extra oil if needed, then cook onions for 5 minutes or until there are nice golden patches.

itemListElement.text: Butter and flour: Add butter into pot. Once melted, add garlic and cook for a further 1 minute. Add tomato paste and cook for 2 minutes. Add flour and cook for 2 minutes.
itemListElement.name: Butter and flour: Add butter into pot. Once melted, add garlic and cook for a further 1 minute. Add tomato paste and cook for 2 minutes. Add flour and cook for 2 minutes.

itemListElement.text: Add wine and stock: While stirring, slowly pour in beef stock – this helps the flour dissolve lump-free into the stock. Then add the reduced wine and mix until flour mixture is dissolved and mostly lump-free. (Note 8)
itemListElement.name: Add wine and stock: While stirring, slowly pour in beef stock – this helps the flour dissolve lump-free into the stock. Then add the reduced wine and mix until flour mixture is dissolved and mostly lump-free. (Note 8)

itemListElement.text: Add everything back in: Add chicken, bacon, mushroom, thyme, bay leaf, salt and pepper into the pot, then stir.
itemListElement.name: Add everything back in: Add chicken, bacon, mushroom, thyme, bay leaf, salt and pepper into the pot, then stir.

itemListElement.text: Oven 45 minutes: Bring to a simmer, then cover and transfer to oven for 45 minutes. Chicken will be very tender - but not "falling apart". (Note 9)
itemListElement.name: Oven 45 minutes: Bring to a simmer, then cover and transfer to oven for 45 minutes. Chicken will be very tender - but not "falling apart". (Note 9)

itemListElement.text: Adjust salt: Remove from oven, taste sauce and add salt if needed.
itemListElement.name: Adjust salt: Remove from oven, taste sauce and add salt if needed.

itemListElement.text: Leave overnight (recommended, Note 11): If time permits, leave the stew overnight before serving because as with all stews, it gets better with time! Reheat gently on a low stove in a covered pot, ensuring that chicken is fully heated through. Add water if needed to loosen sauce.

Reheat gently on a low stove in a covered pot, ensuring that chicken is fully heated through. Add water if needed to loosen sauce.

itemListElement.text: Serve over mashed potato or tagliatelle, sprinkled with fresh parsley! For the ultimate experience, mop the plate clean with homemade brioche (surprisingly straight forward to make). See in post for side salad and dessert options.

review.reviewBody:
You weren't kidding when you said it was more delicious on day 2 (and 3!)
I sopped the sauce with homemade sourdough and all was right with the world. AMAZING.
Made this for a dinner party and it was a great hit. Highly recommend
Made it for my BF for his bday. Made the homemade beef stock and was well worth the extra time. Huge hit. It’s easy enough but labor and time intensive.

This recipe worked excellently. Many thanks. I had to improvise leaks for the small onions, but that still worked I think. Thumbs up from the family, so must have. BTW I like how you present and explain the recipes, including the notes. Really clear. I also loved your roast pork loin recipe, which I did the other week. You were absolutely right. The crackling turned out amazingly. Thanks again. .
Amazing 👏 recipe with an amazing depth of flavour. Well worth the time to marinate and leave overnight. It was a 5 star thumbs up thankyou
Fantastic! Tender tasty and very authentic
The sauce was divine but our thighs were disappointingly dense and chewy. I assume that's down to the quality of the meat and not the recipe. Not sure what we could do to fix that.
Superb. Substituted gammon steak cut in small squares for bacon, used boneless chicken thighs and small shallots. Sauce thickened perfectly during cooking. Thank you Nagi.

Absolutely fabulous, especially for chicken thighs that are tough. Would like to suggest, however, that leaving overnight should include “in the fridge”. I’ve had several people tell me that they thought it safe to leave on the counter overnight because of the wine in it! Love your cookbook and can’t wait for the next one! Need more Dozer please!
